Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:3RY4-57F0-00BT-M0PC-00000-00URGENT GOMA, Zaire: the telephone.''1997-04-09T00:00:00Z2020-08-04T18:48:53ZLexisNexisInternational newsURGENT GOMA, Zaire: the telephone.''

Kabila, wearing a white shirt with a black pinstripe and black pants, met with journalists in a palace that once belonged to Mobutu.

He welcomed Wednesday's White House statement urging Mobutu to make way for a transitional government.

''I think they are right by saying it now,'' he said. ''Everybody knows that this is the time for Mr. Mobutu to get out of power.''

Asked about Mobutu's ouster Wednesday of his recently named prime minister, Etienne Tshishekedi, Kabila used a sporting metaphor to dismiss the significance of the move.

''Everyone sees there is chaos in Kinshasa,'' he said. ''He (Mobutu) tried to use Mr. Tsishekedi … to use him against Mr. Kabila so that people will be watching something like a football match between Kabila and Tsishekedi, in which Mr. Mobutu can (act) as a referee. He has no success at all, because for us, we know who is Mobutu.''
